messages.text: I'm thinking about a new language though. One that could really incentivize developers. So - everytime they write a character it costs 0.0001 cents, every bug costs 0.001 cents. Each successful unique build yields 0.0001 cents. Thinking of calling it "captialism lang". Think about it you could really flaunt your status by naming variables like "newvariabletostore10floats"

messages.text:
JSON-LD snippets embedded in webpages are amazing, and show up all over the place randomly.
And thanks to <http://schema.org|schema.org> are consistent enough to be useful
Anyone actually found use for them?

DataDepsGenerators.jl uses them to generate julia code to download datasets, while keeping all metadata; which is cool because it works for tons of different sites.

messages.text:
You know how you see in books approximations for really large values?  For example, I just read a book saying that 26! is approximately 2^88.  Is there a non-brute-force way to programmatically find a “nice” approximation for any given number?  Is it subjective what “nice” looks like?  I wrote this brute-force method:
```actual = factorial(big(26)); res = (0, 0); for i in 1:4, j in 1:100
    difference = (actual - big(i)^(j))
    if difference > 0
        if difference < (actual - big(first(res))^(last(res)))
            res = (i, j)
        end
    end
end```
But again, this is brute force (indeed it does find that 2^88 is the “nicest” approximation for base numbers between 1 and 4, and exponents between 1 and 100.  But is there a better way?

elements.text: You know how you see in books approximations for really large values?  For example, I just read a book saying that 26! is approximately 2^88.  Is there a non-brute-force way to programmatically find a “nice” approximation for any given number?  Is it subjective what “nice” looks like?  I wrote this brute-force method:

actual = factorial(big(26)); res = (0, 0); for i in 1:4, j in 1:100
    difference = (actual - big(i)^(j))
    if difference > 0
        if difference < (actual - big(first(res))^(last(res)))
            res = (i, j)
        end
    end
end
But again, this is brute force (indeed it does find that 2^88 is the “nicest” approximation for base numbers between 1 and 4, and exponents between 1 and 100.  But is there a better way?

messages.text:
I encourage readers of this thread to look at Jaynes, who provided a pretty rigorous justification for the extension of logic in terms of probability. In particular, you might like <https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cox%27s_theorem|https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cox%27s_theorem> and may follow up with <https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjective_logic|https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjective_logic>

I suspect this is what the tweeter was getting at? Why they didn’t just reference Jaynes is beyond me - especially because it fits in 140 characters (or whatever).

attachments.title: Cox's theorem
attachments.text: Cox's theorem, named after the physicist Richard Threlkeld Cox, is a derivation of the laws of probability theory from a certain set of postulates. This derivation justifies the so-called "logical" interpretation of probability, as the laws of probability derived by Cox's theorem are applicable to any proposition. Logical (also known as objective Bayesian) probability is a type of Bayesian probability. Other forms of Bayesianism, such as the subjective interpretation, are given other justifications.

attachments.title: Subjective logic
attachments.text:
Subjective logic is a type of probabilistic logic that explicitly takes epistemic uncertainty and source trust into account. In general, subjective logic is suitable for modeling and analysing situations involving uncertainty and relatively unreliable sources. For example, it can be used for modeling and analysing trust networks and Bayesian networks.
Arguments in subjective logic are subjective opinions about state variables which can take values from a domain (aka state space), where a state value can be thought of as a proposition which can be true or false. A binomial opinion applies to a binary state variable, and can be represented as a Beta PDF (Probability Density Function). A multinomial opinion applies to a state variable of multiple possible values, and can be represented as a Dirichlet PDF (Probability Density Function). Through the correspondence between opinions and Beta/Dirichlet distributions, subjective logic provides an algebra for these functions. Opinions are also related to the belief representation in Dempster–Shafer belief theory.
A fundamental aspect of the human condition is that nobody can ever determine with absolute certainty whether a proposition about the world is true or false. In addition, whenever the truth of a proposition is expressed, it is always done by an individual, and it can never be considered to represent a general and objective belief. These philosophical ideas are directly reflected in the mathematical formalism of subjective logic.

elements.text: I encourage readers of this thread to look at Jaynes, who provided a pretty rigorous justification for the extension of logic in terms of probability. In particular, you might like
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cox%27s_theorem
and may follow up with
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjective_logic
I suspect this is what the tweeter was getting at? Why they didn’t just reference Jaynes is beyond me - especially because it fits in 140 characters (or whatever).

messages.text: I having trouble building Julia master on Windows, and I finally figured out why. My Cygwin PATH meant llvm-config.exe was trying to link LLVM.dll from my Julia 1.5 install. llvm-config.exe would just fail silently.

messages.text: It pointed here <https://www.hpcwire.com/2021/01/13/julia-update-adoption-keeps-climbing-is-it-a-python-challenger/>

attachments.title: Julia Update: Adoption Keeps Climbing; Is It a Python Challenger?
attachments.text: The rapid adoption of Julia, the open source, high level programing language with roots at MIT, shows no sign of slowing according to data from
attachments.fallback: HPCwire: Julia Update: Adoption Keeps Climbing; Is It a Python Challenger?

elements.text: It pointed here

messages.text:
```January 13, 2021

The rapid adoption of Julia, the open source, high level programing language with roots at MIT, shows no sign of slowing according to data from <http://Julialang.org|Julialang.org>. In 2020, the number of downloads jumped 87 percent to more than 24 million (2020 v. 2019) and the number of available packages rose 73 percent to roughly 4800. Last year (2019 v. 2018) the number of downloads jumped 77 percent. In the most recent TIOBE index, Julia jumped from #47 to #23 and TIOBE CEO Paul Jansen said Julia is the top candidate to jump into the top 20 (used languages) next year.

Julia is hot.```

elements.text:
January 13, 2021

The rapid adoption of Julia, the open source, high level programing language with roots at MIT, shows no sign of slowing according to data from Julialang.org. In 2020, the number of downloads jumped 87 percent to more than 24 million (2020 v. 2019) and the number of available packages rose 73 percent to roughly 4800. Last year (2019 v. 2018) the number of downloads jumped 77 percent. In the most recent TIOBE index, Julia jumped from #47 to #23 and TIOBE CEO Paul Jansen said Julia is the top candidate to jump into the top 20 (used languages) next year.

Julia is hot.

elements.text: Been thinking about this piece lately. Probably one of the most revolutionary pieces of music I have ever heard:

messages.text:
I find it interesting that people constantly compare Python and Julia on HN from the perspective of “there can only be one” — it’s like, _you can use Python from Julia._

I can basically predict what the distribution of comments is going to be before even opening the threads now. There’s some Python fan people complaining about young ecosystem issues in Julia, some other people complaining about time to plot. Some other people pearl clutching TIOBE as if that’s relevant _at all_ to composable, scientific software engineering.

The whole thing baffles me. It’s like people momentarily forget what an API is. Or that *gasp* you can and should use multiple languages together when necessary.

elements.text: I find it interesting that people constantly compare Python and Julia on HN from the perspective of “there can only be one” — it’s like,
you can use Python from Julia.

I can basically predict what the distribution of comments is going to be before even opening the threads now. There’s some Python fan people complaining about young ecosystem issues in Julia, some other people complaining about time to plot. Some other people pearl clutching TIOBE as if that’s relevant
at all

to composable, scientific software engineering.

The whole thing baffles me. It’s like people momentarily forget what an API is. Or that
gasp
you can and should use multiple languages together when necessary.

messages.text: One counterpoint to my perspective above — there is an inherent complexity _at an organization level_ when heterogeneous tooling exists across different projects. So if someone says “well, most of our teams are using Python”, there is a valid argument to be made against introducing a new tool. But I also am opinionated that Julia’s language abstractions far exceeds Python’s abstractions when it comes to large-scale engineering projects which include scientific / numerical components.

elements.text: One counterpoint to my perspective above — there is an inherent complexity
at an organization level

when heterogeneous tooling exists across different projects. So if someone says “well, most of our teams are using Python”, there is a valid argument to be made against introducing a new tool. But I also am opinionated that Julia’s language abstractions far exceeds Python’s abstractions when it comes to large-scale engineering projects which include scientific / numerical components.

messages.text: That same complexity (or cost of two languages) also exists in individual software projects, and in ecosystems. Not to mention the personal cost of having to learn a language if you don't want to. How many orgs do you know who use Perl and Python side by side, together when necessary?

elements.text: That same complexity (or cost of two languages) also exists in individual software projects, and in ecosystems. Not to mention the personal cost of having to learn a language if you don't want to. How many orgs do you know who use Perl and Python side by side, together when necessary?

messages.text:
For old projects, I think FFI wrappers, APIs, macros and/or transpilers can get you most if not all the way. It's a question of which language to pick for a new project. I think if your only reason for choosing language X for a new project is "because everyone around me is using language X" or because "I can only call such and such libraries in language X" when you can call the same libraries with FFI or such from language Y, then it's not a technical reason anymore that's stopping you from switching, it's social and psychological, legitimate as it may be. I think some common social and psychological reasons are:
1. "I am already good enough in language X and I don't have too much time to learn a new language.".
2. "Even if I had or could find the time, I am not confident language Y is here to remain so I don't want to waste my time learning a dying technology. I would rather spend time learning something else, doing more work, spending more time with family, etc."
3. "I am not comfortable going against the tide using a different language than everyone around me."
I think if academia and the major tech giants start moving way from C, C++, Python, Matlab and Java towards Julia, Rust, Swift, Go and Kotlin, the rest of the world will follow for the same reasons they are reluctant to make the switch now. But it takes time. I don't think Julia will ever dominate and it's not supposed to in order to be successful. Julia makes a certain set of design decisions and compromises and every language makes a slightly different set of such compromises. It's good to have the choice between different tradeoffs. So now it's Julia vs Python. 10 years from now, it will be probably Julia vs Swift, Julia vs Go or Julia vs some new language.

elements.text: For old projects, I think FFI wrappers, APIs, macros and/or transpilers can get you most if not all the way. It's a question of which language to pick for a new project. I think if your only reason for choosing language X for a new project is "because everyone around me is using language X" or because "I can only call such and such libraries in language X" when you can call the same libraries with FFI or such from language Y, then it's not a technical reason anymore that's stopping you from switching, it's social and psychological, legitimate as it may be. I think some common social and psychological reasons are:
"I am already good enough in language X and I don't have too much time to learn a new language.".

"Even if I had or could find the time, I am not confident language Y is here to remain so I don't want to waste my time learning a dying technology. I would rather spend time learning something else, doing more work, spending more time with family, etc."
"I am not comfortable going against the tide using a different language than everyone around me."

I think if academia and the major tech giants start moving way from C, C++, Python, Matlab and Java towards Julia, Rust, Swift, Go and Kotlin, the rest of the world will follow for the same reasons they are reluctant to make the switch now. But it takes time. I don't think Julia will ever dominate and it's not supposed to in order to be successful. Julia makes a certain set of design decisions and compromises and every language makes a slightly different set of such compromises. It's good to have the choice between different tradeoffs. So now it's Julia vs Python. 10 years from now, it will be probably Julia vs Swift, Julia vs Go or Julia vs some new language.
